The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: learned a lot about forensic geoscience and geoscience techniques
This course really helped me get a better grasp for reading scientific papers as well as discussing a variety of topics in research.
Insights into a broad range of geologic and seismic material.
reading science lit

In addition to a wide range of knowledge I obtained about the field of forensic geoscience, I felt like I learned how to read science papers and how to make sense of scientific literature. I feel like I developed the ability to think critically about scientific research and research methods, and also was able to connect scientific concepts to non-scientific disciplines, like politics and history.

- How to read scientific papers
- Critical thinking about what scientific results mean, especially in the context of the law
- Some basic chemistry and geoscience 
- Lots of case studies on how forensic geoscience has been used!

I think I benefited a lot from this course because though not a traditional introductory hard science course, I learned a lot about the ways forensic science is used right now to solve a myriad of problems that I was unaware of previously. We learned about current topics of detecting nuclear testing by certain countries, induced seismicity, discussed what role science plays into the entire discussion of risks and how scientists should present their information. I learned a lot of things -- almost like cool science trivia!
Learned about principles in forensics through various case studies that range from military, criminal, seismic, meteorological subjects.
so much about EPS generally! great overview of so many interesting case studies

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Maureen is the best Professor ever!

you cover a ton of different geoscience techniques which are distilled down to basic scientific concepts. you go through material really fast, and there is a lot of peer to peer learning which i really liked. no weaknesses on my end - sometimes the material got a bit dry and technical (in my case i was looking for a good, memorable but not gutty SC credit to take) but it's better than other SC credits i've taken before.
Maureen is a wonderful professor who is excellent at explaining concepts to non-stem majors. The assignments are rewarding and I learned useful skills, like how to read scientific papers.
This course was amazing. The assignments varied enough to keep everything interesting and the organization was great.

The main strengths of the course like with Maureen. She truly is a gem of a professor incredibly kind, engaging, and supportive of her students. Especially given the fact that this semester was really challenging on us for a number of reasons, Maureen was so accommodating and really went out of her way to make the semester as manageable and enjoyable for us as possible. In terms of the course, I think it offers a nice change of structure from many other science courses. Being taught as a seminar, with discussion and participation a big part of classes, makes the course especially engaging for non-STEM majors like me. Additionally, the course is really accessible to students of all science backgrounds, which I also loved because it meant I got to be in class with students from all different majors.

Strengths:
- Professor Long is an absolute gem
- Readings can be hard but incredibly helpful in improving your ability to read complicated information and evaluate it
- Presenting a case study and writing a paper will make you deeply knowledgeable about a topic you may have never heard of before; it is super fun to dive that deep into the unfamiliar and it also very empowering to learn that you can understand complicated information if you break it down using the techniques you learn in the class

Weaknesses
- Class is very very focused on student presentations -- this is nice but occasionally tiring, sometimes would have preffered to hear more of the professor's/TA's input on the topic

I think a strength and weakness is the structure of the class. We would always start with the case study and then go into discussion -- I feel like it might've been beneficial if there was more fluidity in the discussion because it felt somewhat like a Q&A between the presenter and Maureen vs. the rest of the class. Though, I also appreciated the organization of the class -- it was well prepared for and all of the information for the class was easily accessible.

The course lets students engage closely with a particular topic that they chose for their presentation. I also liked that the term paper was due at the 3/4th point in the semester instead of the end because it lessened my workload at the end of the semester.

Strengths: grading is fair and expectations are clear. Instructor is very approachable and the subject is not difficult to understand for non-stem majors. 
Weaknesses: felt that some case studies were inherently treated with higher importance so balancing can perhaps be more considered.
it's really an excellent course. sometimes it would be nice to take things a little slower, but that's really it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Long made a great class despite it being an online seminar.
I think the live seminar over Zoom worked well given the virtual format of the semester. I also appreciated that we had some prerecorded lectures, especially towards the beginning of the semester.

This course went really well considering COVID restrictions, however because it was previously a very hands on course, we did miss out on quite an experience. It would've been fun to go to the cemetery and use a ground penetrating radar sensor or going to the lab and seeing a mass spec, and this might've built relationships between classmates. It was enjoyable to take, nonetheless.
maureen just built up such a great atmosphere in the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Maureen is a caring and engaging professor who cares about her students. Take any class from her you can!

yes, i came into this class a bit hesitant about my interest in the material, and came out of it pretty interested in forensic geoscience and knowledgeable about it. if you're looking for a true gutty science, this might not be it - but i was choosing between this class and a gut SC, and ended up taking this class and have 0 regrets. you learn so much interesting content about the world, how data is measured and analyzed, and phenomena that happen that are actually super, super interesting (and help solve crimes!).
Yes!
Absolutely. I think any course taught by Prof. Long should be recommended even to students not in the sciences. It was an a amazing class.
Yes.
Yes, Professor Long was an excellent and engaging lecturer and discussion leader who facilitated learning on every level.
good science credit for someone with no science background

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students, especially to those looking to fulfill their science distribution credits. Not only is this class really interesting, but Maureen is an incredible professor, and the material is taught in a way that is accessible to all students, and makes for some really great conversation and discussion. Take this class if you can get a seat, you won't regret it!

Yes!!! Fascinating material. Fantastic professor. If you put the time into the readings (!!!!!!), you will learn a lot!!!! Do not take this class if you want to skim them - you will learning nothing. Come ready to engage in the material and you will have a very joyous learning experience.

Yes, Maureen is a super nice professor: she's super understanding and supportive of her students. You definitely learn about a lot of interesting case studies and it's an experience to take a science class that's not in the traditional lecture style. If you take it any other year, you will probably have a more hands-on experience and go see mass specs in labs and such.

This class is good if you enjoy reading scientific papers and having semi-technical but engaging discussions about ethical concerns with science, the scientific method, implications of scientific findings, etc.

I recommend this course to all students who are interested in studying post- incident reports, autopsies, and important events that have considerable social and political consequences from a scientific community perspective.
yes! excellent science credit. made me like learning about hard science stuff again. would recommend

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: async recorded lectures
Recorded lectures
Some prerecorded lectures in place of a live class
We had 5 asynchronous lectures, but most of our class sections were seminar formatted, where a student presents a case study and we discuss afterwards!
n/a
